column4: Original_notes
(+); 1, 2, or 3 years of cultivation followed by 7 years or more follow (field returns to bush) — but will be reopened when fertile again
hoe [underlined]; “…The hoe … is lacking”
winnowing tray [underlined]
Traditionally the men were primarily hunters
(+); now practiced. Traditionally?
for reassignment [underlined]; cf. [trait] #106
chief (govt), king, or other officials [underlined]
“small beans” and fruit trees are now grown this way – a recent development
“Recently the have begun to eat chickens & pigs, which they have obtained from the Chinese.”
bullocks are now used to pull carts
Houses in the Toroku hamlets are built along either side of a wide straight path; but these hamlets were organized by the Japanese police
clans, territorially based, with 8 to 30 fams.
The Rukai and the Tsou, 2 other Formosan tribes, still have a “bachelors’ house” in each village. The Tayal have none.
of unworked stones [underlined]
customarily [underlined]
whose primary purpose is not defensive [underlined]; fortifications around dwellings [underlined] - ?
They are just building a jeep road now
suspension bridges up to 30 m.
not necessarily staffed [underlined]
Even the old “firewood” type dwelling or field shelter has rectangular ground plan
or rebuilt [underlined]
just introduced. In the Japanese style
or other structures [underlined]; Paiwan and Rukai are justly famous for their carved beams. No evidence that the Tayal ever had any.
? (-); slate slabs – unworked. But cf. Guérin & Bernard (1868: 557): bamboo covered with thatch
including palm and bamboo [underlined]
but excluding loopholes [underlined]

?; “Every clan is permanent owner of a fixed piece of arable land of about 100 to 130 hectares in size. No one knows how or when this land was assigned to the clan. Every fam. of the clan may take as much of this clan land as it wishes" (p. 16-17). "As long as the fam. is making use of its plot of ground, their possession of it is protected. As soon as they leave it… any other family of the clan can take possession of it.” (p. 17 [4])
Informants showed me boundary stones and also taboo markers which are still considered effective
?; a clan with growing numbers may buy land from one in decline. But this is probably rare.
under Nat’list govt. auspices since the return
this idea is viewed with some abhorrence

[not marked with + nor -]; Economic* stratification?; * “The richest man in the tribe is said to have 250 [units]. The next richest ...80… Since the fams have an average of 20-30, there are no great inequalities of income. As to other possessions, there is almost no diff. among fams.”
Marriage feasts
ledgers [underlined]

owned and in the possession of a person at the time of his death (exclude property lent out and still outstanding [underlined]?; buried [underlined]; “… all the hunting & fighting equipment which the savage used during his lifetime follows him into the tomb.”; Only “money-cloths” and provisions are passed on.
(-); Carpentry now fits this definition perfectly. Traditionally? No, according to Wiedfeldt (1914: 35)
tatooing
?; an ornamental [underlined]
?; (Most) significant amount [underlined]; Is 133. meaningful if the amount is less that “significant”?
including coins [underlined]
?? (+); None, acc. to Wiedfeldt (1914: 38-39); But: “Atayal Economy has… marketable wares for which there is supply & demand.”
According to Guerin & Bernard (1868: 524 [3]) commerce w/ Chinese was already “playing a vital role” as early as 1866, their field date. But cf. Wiedfeldt (1914: 38-39)
The Tayal produced no finished goods but cloth.
? (+); who are members of the society itself [underlined]; Half-castes (Chi mother) who probably qualify under this def.
?; outside the market area [underlined]
?; class [underlined] - legally recognized status group?
Reciprocal assistance with a cash value assigned to work is now common. Probably developed out of kin obligations, but informants regard it as an ancient and honorable institution
unskilled [underlined]
(+); This is now organized by the state-inspired “village govt.”
?; 1) under unified supervision produce goods by performing [underlined]; 2) differentiated tasks [underlined]
villages [underlined]
excluding required contributions to community projects or ceremonies [underlined]
Official [underlined] ?; excluding [underlined]; Specialized Differentiated
ritual league (gaga); “Hunting league” – Asai (1950: 2-3); H.L. = dekane: 4 or 5 clans – Wiedfeldt (1914: 16 [2]); On family systems, see Asai (1950: 1-2)
work groups (gaga)
?? (-); McGovern (1922: 159); Not mentioned in Hagenauer (1929) or Guerin & Bernard (1868)

one class [underlined]; [symbol] tattoo indicates proficiency in weaving, bracelets signify the number of designs a girl can weave. On a man, if worn on both arms, they show that he has gone head-hunting
All full-fledged adult males hunted
Burial described in Guérin & Bernard (1868: 562)

(+); On polit. org. & law & J.P. in general, Wiedfeldt (1913) is the best source I have found. But the strength of the tribal chief and council may well be merely a response to the threat posed by the Japanese. cf. Wiedfeldt (1914: 32 [3]) on this point; “The magistrate’s power & influence are based entirely on his wealth & courage” (Guerin & Bernard 1868: 563 [3])
“The son does not replace his father unless he is considered worthy of it” (Guerin & Bernard 1868: 563 [3]). But “The office of chief is hereditary” (Wiedfeldt 1914: 25 [4])
clan chiefs [underlined]
He speaks first in council
(-); Fines [underlined] - Not for his personal use. Held for the clan.
Chief hears complains of theft
only by mediation [underlined]

?; explicitly formulated [underlined]; murder (accidental killing, killing of a non-clan tribesman, killing of a clansman), adultery and theft are all recognized and initiative taken by authority if necessary to ensure punishment
under law [underlined]
under law [underlined]
under law [underlined]
?; an adulterer’s hut is burned as punishment, but never confiscated
Head-hunting tied in with ancestor-worship
40 cm. bush knives acquired from Chinese “presumably within the last generation.” Traditionally, only bow & throwing spears
no shields or helmets either
heads [underlined]
(-); awarded [underlined]; By custom, a successful head-hunter has extra tatooing under his lower lip
?; Increased prestige & influence in council, but no special privileges
Heads offered; but is headhunting really a “military” campaign?
(+); skull-racks
the female tattooer may be so supported, but this is qua service sp. rather than relig. sp.
No specialist but the greatest importance is given to omens, especially to bird augury

platform beds [underlined]
unraveling and reweaving [underlined]
jewelry [underlined]
Jap. trade rings of brass or bronze; Note: Jap. jewelry a “recent” import (field date: 1913). Traditonal ornaments were bamboo earplugs, dried berry & animal-tooth necklaces
[Innovative]?
jew’s harp made with bamboo & copper (chinese trade metal)
But the rice-paper plant was cultivated
